titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I went in to Durham, and again attended the meeting of the Sub–Committee. The accounts of the Cathedral were considered, and I was amused by the Receiver's candid confession that "for himself he could not distinguish between a plough and a turnip". I was impressed by the intelligence with which the Bishop of St E. and J. conducted the business. He was plainly at home in the sphere of finance. The cost of the Choir, including the incomes of the 4 minor canons, is about £6000 per annum. I lunched with the Bishop of Jarrow and Mrs Knight, & then returned to Auckland, and paid the month's house accounts. The first number of the 'Bishoprick' made its 'débût. It has a mud–coloured cover, and is monstrously dull. I motored to Annfield Plain, and there "admitted" Dick to the perpetual curacy of St Aidan's, in succession to the unctuous and intolerable Talbot. The mean little iron church was barely filled with a congregation, in which the devout sex predominated. There was a good attendance of the local clergy, headed by the Rural Dean. At intervals sounds from without reminded us that Guy Fawkes had still some observants! After service I returned to Auckland.

"Sir, thou hast nothing to draw with, and the well is deep" – this was Ralph's sufficient criticism of Carnegie's new book on "Anglicanism". My sapient friend, who is more deaf than ever, went off about noon. He has gained a surprisingly prominence among his contemporaries.

"The newspapers have discovered that I am good 'copy', and they are working up a 'stunt'", he observed with reference to the rather hectic headlines, which announced a review of his essay in the newly published volume, 'Science, Religion and Reality". I asked him whether he would have gone to the Westminster Deanery if he had been offered the opportunity, & he replied that the transfer had been discussed. He would remain at St Paul's until the public wearied of him. We groaned together over the gloomy future which lay before civilization. He thought the western world was marching to a great catastrophe; but, perhaps two centuries ahead, the world might recover. I pointed out that the worse feature in the present situation was the evident deterioration of humanity itself, and this factor promised nothing but continuous decline. He did not dissent. We parted in a mood of profound depression which not even his wit could lighten.
